name: Bardiya National Park Safari
overview: Experience the wild west of Nepal in Bardiya National Park, the largest and most undisturbed national park in the Terai. It offers the best chance to see the Royal Bengal Tiger in the wild, along with wild elephants and dolphins.
highlights: High probability of spotting Royal Bengal Tigers
detailedDescription: Bardiya is for the true wildlife enthusiast. Far from the crowds of Chitwan, it offers a raw and authentic jungle experience. The park is home to a significant population of tigers, wild elephants, and the one-horned rhino. Activities include full-day jeep safaris, jungle walks with expert trackers, and boating on the Karnali River where you might spot the rare Gangetic dolphin. The Tharu communities here have preserved their traditional lifestyle, adding a rich cultural dimension to the trip.
bestTimeToVisit: October-June. March-May is best for tiger sightings.
culturalTips: Respect the silence of the jungle.

name: Bhaktapur & Patan Tour
overview: Explore the medieval city-states of Bhaktapur and Patan (Lalitpur). Known for their exquisite art, architecture, and well-preserved Durbar Squares, these cities are living museums of Newari culture.
highlights: Patan Durbar Square (City of Fine Arts)
detailedDescription: Step back in time as you wander the brick-paved alleys of Bhaktapur, the 'City of Devotees'. Marvel at the 55-Window Palace and the towering Nyatapola Temple. Watch potters at work in Pottery Square. Then, visit Patan, the 'City of Fine Arts', famous for its metalwork and stone carvings. The Patan Durbar Square is a masterpiece of Shikhar-style architecture, and the Patan Museum is one of the best in South Asia.

name: Rara Lake Trek
overview: Journey to the 'Queen of Lakes', Rara Lake, the largest and deepest freshwater lake in Nepal. Located in the remote Far West, this trek offers solitude, pristine nature, and a glimpse into a rustic way of life.
highlights: Sinja Valley (historical origin of Nepali language)
detailedDescription: The trek to Rara is a journey into the wild. Starting from Jumla or Talcha, the trail passes through pine, spruce, and juniper forests. Rara Lake itself is mesmerizing, changing colors throughout the day. It is surrounded by green hills and snow-capped peaks. The area is sparsely populated, offering a true wilderness experience. A hike to Murma Top offers a panoramic view of the lake and the distant mountains.
culturalTips: Very remote area, expect basic facilities.

name: Dolpo Circuit Trek
overview: Explore the hidden land of Dolpo, popularized by the movie 'Himalaya' (Caravan). This restricted area trek takes you to Phoksundo Lake, Shey Gompa, and high passes, offering a glimpse into the ancient Bon Po religion.
detailedDescription: Upper Dolpo is a high-altitude desert, culturally Tibetan and geographically isolated. The trek is physically demanding, crossing two passes over 5,000m. The highlight is the turquoise Phoksundo Lake, which has no aquatic life due to its unique chemical composition. You'll visit Shey Gompa, a spiritual center, and witness the yak caravans that still trade salt and grain.
bestTimeToVisit: Spring and Autumn. Monsoon is also possible (rain shadow).
culturalTips: Restricted area ($500 permit). Respect Bon tradition.

name: Tsum Valley Trek
overview: Discover the 'Hidden Valley of Happiness'. Tsum Valley is a sacred Himalayan pilgrimage valley situated in northern Gorkha. Known for its ancient monasteries, friendly people, and non-violent culture.
highlights: Views of Ganesh Himal and Manaslu
detailedDescription: Tsum Valley was a restricted area until 2008. The valley is rich in ancient art, culture, and religion. The trails are adorned with artistic chortens and mani walls. The local people, Tsumbas, have their own dialect and unique traditions. You'll visit centuries-old monasteries like Mu Gompa and Rachen Gompa, where monks and nuns reside. The valley offers spectacular views of the Ganesh Himal range.

name: Ama Dablam Expedition
overview: Ama Dablam is often called the 'Matterhorn of the Himalayas'. It is one of the most beautiful and technical mountains to climb. This expedition is for experienced climbers looking for a serious challenge on rock, ice, and snow.
highlights: Summit one of the world's most beautiful peaks
Technical climbing on rock and ice
detailedDescription: Ama Dablam requires technical climbing skills. The route involves steep rock climbing, ice climbing, and scrambling on exposed ridges. The climb is typically done from the Southwest Ridge. Camp 1 is at 5,700m, Camp 2 at 5,900m (on a narrow rock ledge), and Camp 3 at 6,300m (on a hanging glacier). The summit push is steep and demanding but rewards climbers with arguably the finest viewpoint in the Khumbu.
culturalTips: Puja ceremony before climbing is mandatory.

name: Kanchenjunga Base Camp Trek
overview: Trek to the base of the world's third highest mountain, Kanchenjunga (8,586m). This remote trek in eastern Nepal explores both the North and South Base Camps, offering pristine wilderness and diverse flora.
highlights: Views of Kanchenjunga and Jannu Himal
Visit both North and South Base Camps
detailedDescription: The Kanchenjunga region is a restricted area that sees few trekkers. The trail passes through the Kanchenjunga Conservation Area, known for its rhododendron forests and wildlife. You'll visit the North Base Camp (Pangpema) for views of the massive North Face, and the South Base Camp (Oktang) for views of the Yalung Glacier. It's a long, strenuous trek that rewards with solitude and grandeur.

name: Makalu Base Camp Trek
overview: A journey to the base of the world's 5th highest peak, Makalu (8,481m). This trek takes you deep into the Makalu Barun National Park, a place of spectacular high-altitude scenery and rich biodiversity.
highlights: Close-up view of Makalu and Everest (Kangshung face)
detailedDescription: The trek begins from the lush lowlands of Tumlingtar and ascends into the high Himalayas. You'll cross the Shipton La pass into the remote Barun Valley, a sanctuary of pristine forests and alpine meadows. Makalu Base Camp offers a stunning amphitheater of peaks. It is a rugged trek for those seeking solitude and raw nature.

name: Lobuche East Peak Climbing
overview: Lobuche East is a popular trekking peak that offers a slightly more technical challenge than Island Peak. It provides stunning views of Everest, Lhotse, Nuptse, and Ama Dablam.
highlights: Views of Everest and Khumbu Glacier
detailedDescription: The climb involves a trek to Everest Base Camp for acclimatization. From Lobuche village, you ascend to High Camp near a glacial lake. The summit day involves climbing on snow and ice (45-50 degrees) and a final ridge walk. The summit offers one of the best views of Everest in the region.
